questions.text: A 30-year-old woman Aishwarya goes to her gynecologist Dr. Raina Chawla for a pre-pregnancy examination. Routine prenatal laboratory testing demonstrates normal hematological profile with controlled sugar as well negative TORCH infections. She normal liver function tests with the following profile: HBsAg negative, anti- HBcAg (-), anti- HBeAg (-), HBV DNA polymerase (-) but anti- HBsAg is positive. Which of the following likely represents the status of the patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Infected with hepatitis B and highly transmissible

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Immunized against hepatitis B

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Hepatitis B carrier: This status would be indicated by the presence of hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) in the serum for more than six months . A carrier is also often positive for hepatitis B e antigen (HBeAg) or has detectable levels of HBV DNA, reflecting ongoing replication of the virus. However, this patient is negative for HBsAg, HBeAg, and HBV DNA polymerase, so she is not a carrier.
  • • Option A: Hepatitis B carrier:
  • • presence of hepatitis B surface antigen
  • • serum for more than six months
  • • Option C: Immunized against hepatitis B: The presence of antibodies to HBsAg (anti-HBs) without the presence of HBsAg or anti-HBc suggests immunity from vaccination . This is because the hepatitis B vaccine contains HBsAg, which stimulates the production of anti-HBs without causing an infection.
  • • Option C: Immunized against hepatitis B:
  • • presence of antibodies to HBsAg
  • • presence of HBsAg or anti-HBc
  • • immunity from vaccination
  • • Option D: Infected with hepatitis B and highly transmissible: If the patient were infected and highly infectious , we would expect to see positive HBeAg and HBV DNA polymerase since these are markers of high levels of viral replication and infectivity . However, this patient is negative for both.
  • • Option D: Infected with hepatitis B and highly transmissible:
  • • infected and highly infectious
  • • positive HBeAg and HBV DNA polymerase
  • • markers of high levels of viral replication
  • • infectivity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of anti-HBsAg in the absence of HBsAg and other markers of infection indicates that the patient has been successfully immunized against hepatitis B. The hepatitis B vaccine induces the production of anti-HBs antibodies, which provide immunity to the virus.
  • ➤ presence of anti-HBsAg
  • ➤ absence of HBsAg
  • ➤ markers of infection
  • ➤ patient has been successfully immunized against hepatitis B.

  • • spread through sexual contact
  • • chronic carrier status
  • • less commonly associated
  • • mode of transmission

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with fatigue, hepatomegaly, and neurological symptoms such as tremors and dysarthria. Ophthalmic examination reveals a brownish ring around the cornea.   • • hereditary condition
  • • excessive iron accumulation
  • • organs
  • • Option D: Primary biliary cirrhosis: Primary biliary cirrhosis is an autoimmune liver disease characterized by the destruction of intrahepatic bile ducts . While it may lead to cirrhosis and associated symptoms, it does not cause the ophthalmic findings seen in Wilson’s disease.
